channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Californians hospitalized with COVID-19 at lowest level in 6 months
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: The average number of daily deaths has also dropped to its lowest point since May.
item.content:encoded: The average number of daily deaths has also dropped to its lowest point since May.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - OCTOBER 07: Lunctime crowd in downtown Ventura on Wednesday, Oct. 7, 2020. Data released by the California Department of Public Health on Tuesday confirmed that Ventura County has moved into the less restrictive red tier. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Federal stimulus checks must go to prison inmates, U.S. judge in California rules
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: After months of confusion, a federal judge in California has ruled the IRS must give stimulus checks to more than 2 million prison inmates nationwide.
item.content:encoded: After months of confusion, a federal judge in California has ruled the IRS must give stimulus checks to more than 2 million prison inmates nationwide.

media:content.media:description: FILE- In this April 23, 2020, file photo a stimulus check issued by the IRS to help combat the adverse economic effects of the COVID-19 outbreak is shown in San Antonio. Compounding the hardships of coronavirus, some nursing homes have demanded that low-income residents turn over their $1,200 economic stimulus checks. On Tuesday, June 9, Sens. Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa, and Ron Wyden, D-Ore., called on the Health and Human Services inspector general's office to issue a warning to nursing homes and assisted living facilities that such practices are "improper and unlawful." (AP Photo/Eric Gay, File)

item.title: 2 drivers mistake gas pedal for brake, leaving 1 dead and several hospitalized in San Jose
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: One person who was struck in the unrelated crashes died of his injuries, police said.
item.content:encoded: One person who was struck in the unrelated crashes died of his injuries, police said.

media:content.media:description: Police investigate the area where a driver slammed into an outdoor dinning area at Grand Century Plaza in San Jose, Calif., on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2020. Two people were in critical condition Monday after being injured when a man drove his SUV into an outdoor dining area, hitting a pedestrian and several diners in Northern California, authorities said. Eight people were taken to the hospital with injuries described as "major to minor." (Randy Vazquez/ Bay Area News Group via AP)

item.title: COVID-19 restrictions may have played a role in San Francisco firefighter's death
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Jason Cortez was alone on the third-floor fire escape of a training facility when he was knocked off by a blast of water, a San Francisco Fire Department report says.
item.content:encoded: Jason Cortez was alone on the third-floor fire escape of a training facility when he was knocked off by a blast of water, a San Francisco Fire Department report says.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CA - OCT. 7: Family and friends of deceased SF firefighter and paramedic Jason Cortez head to SFFD vehicles for a procession to Medical Examiner's office from SF General Hospital in San Francisco, Calif., on Wednesday, October 7, 2020. Cortez died Wednesday morning during a training exercise. (Scott Strazzante/The San Francisco Chronicle via Getty Images)
media:content.media:credit: San Francisco Chronicle/Hearst N/Hearst Newspapers via Getty Imag

item.title: California elections officials demand removal of GOP's unofficial ballot drop boxes
item.dc:creator: John Myers, Stephanie Lai
item.description: California's attorney general and secretary of state called such ballot drop boxes illegal and sent a cease-and-desist letter to Republican Party officials.
item.content:encoded: California's attorney general and secretary of state called such ballot drop boxes illegal and sent a cease-and-desist letter to Republican Party officials.

media:content.media:description: An employee of the Orange County Registrar of Voters sorts through mail-in ballots on Wednesday, Nov. 7, 2018 at their facility in Santa Ana. Many races in Orange County remain too close to call. (Nick Agro / For The Times)

item.title: PG&E warns of power outages as high winds, extreme heat roll into Northern California
item.dc:creator: Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Pacific Gas & Electric Co. says parts of as many as 43 counties could see power shutoffs beginning Wednesday and lasting potentially through Friday.
item.content:encoded: Pacific Gas & Electric Co. says parts of as many as 43 counties could see power shutoffs beginning Wednesday and lasting potentially through Friday.

media:content.media:description: A PG&E worker clears a power line blocking a roadway in unincorporated Napa County, Calif., on Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020. Pacific Gas & Electric Co. is preparing for power shut-offs this Wednesday afternoon through potentially Friday morning. (AP Photo/Noah Berger)

item.title: At least 76 arrested in downtown L.A. following Lakers' championship win
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith, Richard Winton, Kevin Rector, Ruben Vives
item.description: The LAPD said more than 30 buildings were damaged, and eight officers and two other people were injured when celebrations turned destructive.
item.content:encoded: The LAPD said more than 30 buildings were damaged, and eight officers and two other people were injured when celebrations turned destructive.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - OCTOBER 11: LAPD clear the are near LA Live declaring an unlawful assembly after the Lakers 106 - 93 game 6 over the Miami Heat on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: High-stakes college recruitment goes virtual, and it's no fun thanks to Zoom fatigue
item.dc:creator: Larry Gordon
item.description: No more high school visits or big gatherings as college recruiters, like everyone else, turn to Zoom. Students are fatigued and stressed.
item.content:encoded: No more high school visits or big gatherings as college recruiters, like everyone else, turn to Zoom. Students are fatigued and stressed.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA., February 4, 2020 âStudents on the campus of UCLA on Tuesday, February 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Exide may be allowed to abandon toxic battery recycling plant and massive cleanup bill
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: A bankruptcy plan by battery recycler Exide would allow it to walk away from California's largest environmental cleanup, leaving taxpayers to pay the bill
item.content:encoded: A bankruptcy plan by battery recycler Exide would allow it to walk away from California's largest environmental cleanup, leaving taxpayers to pay the bill

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - OCTOBER 06: Portions of the Exide Technologies, lead-acid battery recycling plant located in Vernon are wrapped in scaffolding and white plastic even as a press conference with state and local elected leaders was held at Resurrection Church in the Boyle Heights neighborhood of Los Angeles to express their opposition to Exide's proposed bankruptcy settlement, specifically in regard to the option for Exide to fully abandon the facility in Vernon and its responsibility to clean the environmental damage it caused. Resurrection Church on Tuesday, Oct. 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California regulators launch review of long, deadly delays in L.A. County specialty care
item.dc:creator: Jack Dolan, Brittny Mejia
item.description: The review follows a Times investigation that found some patients die while waiting months to see a specialist in the L.A. County public hospital system.
item.content:encoded: The review follows a Times investigation that found some patients die while waiting months to see a specialist in the L.A. County public hospital system.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA, August 24, 2019 - Majid Vatandoust, a 49-year old heating and air conditioning technician from Canoga Park, who went to LAC clinic Mid-Valley for a check-up in early 2014. He had unintentionally lost about 20 pounds and routine tests found he was anemic and had blood in his stool, all early indicators of potentially deadly colon cancer. His doctor put in a request via eConsult for a colonoscopy but was denied, his medical records show. The gastroenterologist who turned down the request without ever seeing Vatandoust said the test used to detect blood in Vatandoust's stool was "not valid for patients under 50 years old." Thousands of patients in L.A. County's public hospital system who endure long, sometimes deadly delays to see medical specialists, a Times investigation has found. Doctors, nurses and patients describe chronic waits that leave the sick with intolerable pain, worsening illnesses and a growing sense of hopelessness. According to a Times data analysis of more than 860,000 requests for specialty care at the L.A. County Department of Health Services, a sprawling safety-net system that serves more than 2 million, primarily the region's poorest and most vulnerable residents. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD data show few officers report excessive force by peers; better tracking promised
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: With a new state law requiring police officers to report excessive force by their peers, the Los Angeles Police Department has only two such documented incidents in the last five years.
item.content:encoded: With a new state law requiring police officers to report excessive force by their peers, the Los Angeles Police Department has only two such documented incidents in the last five years.

media:content.media:description: If contract is approved, LAPD officers would get an 8.2% raise over four years.
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Thank Newsom's childhood pet â an otter â for helping protect California land and waters
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: California Gov. Gavin Newsom has been influenced on environmental issues by by his grandfather, dad â and childhood pet otter, Potter.
item.content:encoded: California Gov. Gavin Newsom has been influenced on environmental issues by by his grandfather, dad â and childhood pet otter, Potter.

media:content.media:description: DELETES REFERENCE TO SOLANO COUNTY - California Gov. Gavin Newsom, center, tastes a walnut while touring Sierra Orchards walnut farm with owner Craig McNamara, right, in Winters, Calif., Wednesday, Oct. 7, 2020. Newsom signed an executive order Wednesday to protect nearly a third of California's land and coastal waters in his latest effort to fight climate change that he has blamed for recent record-breaking wildfires. (RenÃ©e C. Byer/The Sacramento Bee via AP, Pool)

item.title: UC San Diego ends up with 5,000 fewer dorm students than projected, primarily because of coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Gary Robbins
item.description: The university also disclosed last week that the COVID-19 financial losses it expects to suffer will be about $200 million for 2020 and 2021.
item.content:encoded: The university also disclosed last week that the COVID-19 financial losses it expects to suffer will be about $200 million for 2020 and 2021.

media:content.media:description: Students move their belongings into dormitories at UCSD on Saturday, September 19, 2020.(Photo by Sandy Huffaker for The SD Union-Tribune)

item.title: LAPD declares unlawful assembly and begins arresting Lakers revelers outside Staples Center
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Dakota Smith
item.description: Despite officials' pleas to stay away, Lakers faithful flocked to downtown Los Angeles to celebrate the championship. Police blocked entrances to L.A. Live and later declared an unlawful assembly.
item.content:encoded: Despite officials' pleas to stay away, Lakers faithful flocked to downtown Los Angeles to celebrate the championship. Police blocked entrances to L.A. Live and later declared an unlawful assembly.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - OCTOBER 11: A man holds a Kobe Bryant Bl. sign as fellow fans celebrate of the Lakers 106 - 93 championship win over the Miami Heat on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Southern California braces for another heat wave this week
item.dc:creator: Paul Duginski, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: After a brief reprieve of cool temperatures over the weekend, Southern California is expected to get hit with another heat wave this week that could bring periods of elevated fire risk, according to forecasters.
item.content:encoded: After a brief reprieve of cool temperatures over the weekend, Southern California is expected to get hit with another heat wave this week that could bring periods of elevated fire risk, according to forecasters.

media:content.media:description: JUNIPER HILLS, CA - SEPTEMBER 20: A thank-you sign posted by thankful residents is posted as a firetruck races by as the Bobcat fire continues to burn in the Angeles National Forest in Juniper Hills Sunday, Sept. 20, 2020. Some houses and structures in the Juniper Hills area were lost in the Bobcat fire but most were saved. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tens of thousands protest outside L.A.'s Turkish Consulate in solidarity with Armenia
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: About 35,000 protesters marched to the consulate in Beverly Hills, focusing their opposition on Turkey, which has expressed support for Azerbaijan in its deadly conflict with Armenia over a small separatist region populated by ethnic Armenians.
item.content:encoded: About 35,000 protesters marched to the consulate in Beverly Hills, focusing their opposition on Turkey, which has expressed support for Azerbaijan in its deadly conflict with Armenia over a small separatist region populated by ethnic Armenians.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - OCTOBER 11: Thousands from the Armenian community gathered at Pan Pacific Park in Los Angeles to denounce the military aggression by Turkey and Azerbaijan against Armenians in Artsakh. Photographed on Sunday, Oct. 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Officials discover 3,000 pounds of meth at Otay Mesa Port of Entry
item.dc:creator: David Hernandez
item.description: Officials interdicting bundles of meth, heroin and fentanyl on Friday said it was the second-largest meth bust in Customs and Border Protection history.
item.content:encoded: Officials interdicting bundles of meth, heroin and fentanyl on Friday said it was the second-largest meth bust in Customs and Border Protection history.

media:content.media:description: Customs and Border Protection officers found bundles of meth, fentanyl and heroin in a semi-trailer at the Otay Mesa Port of Entry on Friday.

item.title: L.A. County reports 971 new coronavirus cases, 3 deaths
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The county has logged a total of 282,135 cases of the virus, and 6,711 people have died. Officials continued to report encouraging signs of progress.
item.content:encoded: The county has logged a total of 282,135 cases of the virus, and 6,711 people have died. Officials continued to report encouraging signs of progress.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 11: A couple in face masks walk down Cesar E. Chavez Blvd on Saturday morning in Los Angeles. Life around Cesar E. Chavez Blvd. and Soto St. has slow down as California officials extended stay-at-home orders into May and residents entered Easter weekend with unprecedented limits on their movements. Most of the people are adhering to the orders by mayor to wear masks while out running errands. Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Another L.A. County child diagnosed with rare COVID-related syndrome
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga
item.description: A total of 41 children have had the ailment in L.A. County. None of the children have died, but nearly half had to be admitted to intensive care.
item.content:encoded: A total of 41 children have had the ailment in L.A. County. None of the children have died, but nearly half had to be admitted to intensive care.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 04 , 2020 - L.A. County Department of Public Health Director Barbara Ferrer addresses a press conference held at the steps of Kenneth Hahn Hall of Administration to declare a health emergency as the number of coronavirus cases increased to seven, with six new cases in Los Angeles County. None of the new cases are connected to "community spread," officials said. All individuals were exposed to COVID-19 through close contacts. The additional cases were confirmed Tuesday night. Officials said three of the new cases were travelers who had visited northern Italy, two were family members who had close contact with someone outside of the county who was infected, and one had a job that put them in contact with travelers. One person has been hospitalized, and the others are isolated at home. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Irfan Khan/Los Angeles Times

item.title: 3 arrested after stabbing on Santa Monica Pier, police say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Three people were arrested after a stabbing on the Santa Monica Pier wounded several men Saturday night, police said.
item.content:encoded: Three people were arrested after a stabbing on the Santa Monica Pier wounded several men Saturday night, police said.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CALIFORNIA-MARCH 19, 2020-The City of Santa Monica closed the Santa Monica Pier in an attempt to prevent the further spread of the Coronavirus on March 19, 20230. Very few people were on the beach in Santa Monica as the epidemic continues to be a problem. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How L.A.'s Armenian food community has banded together to support their homeland
item.dc:creator: Jenn Harris
item.description: Armenian restaurateurs in Los Angeles are donating profits, using social media, feeding protesters and doing what they can to bring attention to the deadly conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh.
item.content:encoded: Armenian restaurateurs in Los Angeles are donating profits, using social media, feeding protesters and doing what they can to bring attention to the deadly conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh.

media:content.media:description: GLENDALE-CA-OCTOBER 8, 2020: Armen Martirosyan with his father Hovik, left, and mother Alvard, right, are photographed at their restaurant, Mini Kabob in Glendale, on Thursday, October 8, 2020. The Armenian food community is raising awareness of the fighting in Azerbaijan. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's hardest-to-count census tract confronts politics, pandemic and fear
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: A census tract in Stockton is the hardest to count in California, emblematic of the challenges faced by other underserved communities in the state.
item.content:encoded: A census tract in Stockton is the hardest to count in California, emblematic of the challenges faced by other underserved communities in the state.

media:content.media:description: This April 5, 2020, photo shows a 2020 census letter mailed to a U.S. resident in Detroit. The U.S. Census Bureau needs more time to wrap up the once-a-decade count because of the coronavirus, opening the possibility of delays in drawing new legislative districts that could help determine what political party is in power, what laws pass or fail and whether communities of color get a voice in their states. (AP Photo/Paul Sancya)

item.title: Column: The Los Angeles we love is dying in 2020. We must fight to save it
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: The mom-and-pop stores of our metropolis, like Vroman's in Pasadena, are part of L.A.'s spirit and identity. Support them before they're gone.
item.content:encoded: The mom-and-pop stores of our metropolis, like Vroman's in Pasadena, are part of L.A.'s spirit and identity. Support them before they're gone.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA - OCTOBER 06: Joel Sheldon is the owner of Vroman's Bookstore. The Pasadena institution may not make it through the year because of the economic devastation caused by the coronavirus pandemic. Photographed at Vroman's Bookstore on Tuesday, Oct. 6, 2020 in Pasadena, CA. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California kept prison factories open. Inmates worked for pennies an hour as COVID-19 spread
item.dc:creator: Kiera Feldman
item.description: Inmates who made masks and furniture for as little as 35 cents an hour say they felt pressure to stay on the job, even as the coronavirus spread through the prison factories.
item.content:encoded: Inmates who made masks and furniture for as little as 35 cents an hour say they felt pressure to stay on the job, even as the coronavirus spread through the prison factories.

media:content.media:description: Robbie Hall sewed masks at a factory in a women's prison in Chino until she became infected with COVID-19.
media:content.media:credit: Illustration by Alex Tatusian/Los Angeles Times

item.title: L.A. County health officials report 1,285 new coronavirus cases and an additional 28 deaths
item.dc:creator: Christopher Goffard
item.description: In 72% of the new cases, those who tested positive were under 50 years old, officials said.
item.content:encoded: In 72% of the new cases, those who tested positive were under 50 years old, officials said.

media:content.media:description: ARCADIA, CA - OCTOBER 07, 2020 - A sign tells customers to wear masks to prevent the spread of COVID-19 as shoppers return to indoor shopping at the Westfield Santa Anita shopping mall in Arcadia on October 7, 2020. This is the first day customers were allowed to return to indoor shopping after Los Angeles County eased restrictions and have reopened the malls and the individual stores. Such stores have been closed for weeks, but reopened Wednesday at 25% capacity. Westfield Santa Anita has placed Covid-related signage with one-way traffic, 6 feet distancing when waiting to get into individual stores, hand sanitizing stations and mask are required before entering the mall. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA investigates 'Zoom-bombing' attacks during online classes
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: UCLA officials are investigating "Zoom-bombing" incidents in which people disrupted online classes in the first week of the fall term, officials said.
item.content:encoded: UCLA officials are investigating "Zoom-bombing" incidents in which people disrupted online classes in the first week of the fall term, officials said.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - AUGUST 05, 2020 - - A lone jogger runs past Royce Hall on a nearly empty UCLA campus in Los Angeles on August 13, 2020. The empty campus is a preview of what the Fall semester will look like during the coronavirus pandemic. Most classes, much like the summer classes, will be held online at the university. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inequities of pandemic learning on stark display at the Orange County-Long Beach border
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Los Alamitos students in Orange County were among the first in the state to return to campus. Just across the county line, distance learning remains the norm for Long Beach students, frustrating some families.
item.content:encoded: Los Alamitos students in Orange County were among the first in the state to return to campus. Just across the county line, distance learning remains the norm for Long Beach students, frustrating some families.

media:content.media:description: LOS ALAMITOS, CA - OCTOBER 05: Students leave campus after a day of in-class learning at Los Alamitos High School, Monday, Oct. 5, 2020 in Los Alamitos. Los Alamitos Unified School District reopened in September. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Volunteers who help kids in foster care are wanted more than ever during the pandemic
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: When a little girl wound up in foster care, she got help to turn her life around. CASA, the program that provided it, needs many more volunteers.
item.content:encoded: When a little girl wound up in foster care, she got help to turn her life around. CASA, the program that provided it, needs many more volunteers.

media:content.media:description: SANTA MONICA, CA - OCTOBER 1, 2020 Jayne Amelia Larson, a volunteer Court Appointed Special Advocate with CASA, holds a drawing created by a young client she works with in the program. Larson advocates for children and young people in the foster system who have been abused and neglected. Larson is an actor, writer and independent film producer. She wrote the New York Times bestseller, "Driving the Saudis." She was photographed in Santa Monica on October 1, 2020. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With lessons learned from deadly wildfires, Sonoma County improves evacuation planning
item.dc:creator: Joseph Serna
item.description: Three years after its disastrous response to the Tubbs fire, Sonoma County officials say they have found a better approach.
item.content:encoded: Three years after its disastrous response to the Tubbs fire, Sonoma County officials say they have found a better approach.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ROSA, CA - SEPTEMBER 28: Redwood City Firefighters pout out hotspots in burnt out homes and structures in the Skyhawk community, where the Shady fire tore through in the early hours of the morning, photographed on Monday, Sept. 28, 2020 in Santa Rosa, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: She is naked, sick, dirty, crawling across Sunset Boulevard â how can this happen in L.A.?
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Neighbors in Silver Lake have been sounding the alarm, trying to prevent yet another death of a homeless person in a city where it happens far too often. We can't allow this level of suffering to become acceptable.
item.content:encoded: Neighbors in Silver Lake have been sounding the alarm, trying to prevent yet another death of a homeless person in a city where it happens far too often. We can't allow this level of suffering to become acceptable.

media:content.media:description: SILVER LAKE, CA - OCTOBER 09, 2020:Julio Martinez and his girl friend, Crystal Johar, who are homeless and suffer from mental illness, rest together behind a car wash in Silver Lake, where they spend a lot of time. (Mel Melcon / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Here's why Armenian Americans in Southern California are protesting
item.dc:creator: Ada Tseng
item.description: Los Angeles is the home to one of the largest Armenian diasporas. Here's why many are fearful over the recent violence with Azerbaijan in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region, known to Armenians as Artsakh.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles is the home to one of the largest Armenian diasporas. Here's why many are fearful over the recent violence with Azerbaijan in the disputed Nagorno-Karabakh region, known to Armenians as Artsakh.

media:content.media:description: EL SEGUNDO, CA - OCTOBER 06: More than 1,000 people supporting Armenia with flags, signs and song, gathered in protest of the Los Angeles Times using a quote from the Counsul General of Azerbaijan, in a story about the current conflict in the contested Nagorno-Karabakh region between Armenia and Azerbaijan, outside the Los Angeles Times headquarters, in El Segundo, CA,Tuesday, Oct. 6, 2020. Fighting broke out in the region, which Armenians call by its historic name, Artsakh, at the end of September with each side accusing the other of escalation and targeting civilian areas. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How the coronavirus is changing L.A. County's waste stream
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak has indelibly imprinted itself on life in Los Angeles â down to the composition of trash washing up on its beaches.
item.content:encoded: The coronavirus outbreak has indelibly imprinted itself on life in Los Angeles â down to the composition of trash washing up on its beaches.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - OCTOBER 09: A discarded face covering is seen on the beach in Santa Monica on Friday, Oct. 9, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Masks and gloves have made the top ten list for trash found on area beaches. The discovery was made during this year's annual coastal cleanup done by thousands of volunteers. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Southern California suburban counties failing COVID-19 benchmarks for communities of color

Dodger Stadium on Wednesday, July 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: How to become an L.A. County poll worker for the 2020 election
item.dc:creator: Jessica Roy
item.description: Want to help uphold democracy on election day? Consider being a poll worker if you're at low risk for a coronavirus infection. Here's what's involved.
item.content:encoded: Want to help uphold democracy on election day? Consider being a poll worker if you're at low risk for a coronavirus infection. Here's what's involved.

media:content.media:description: La Jolla Community Planning Assocition members who have attended at least one LJCPA meeting between March 2019 and February 2020 are eligible to vote. They must present a photo ID in order to cast a ballot. Additional information can be found at lajollacpa.org

item.title: Private fire crews in wine country raise concerns over equity and safety
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Allegations have emerged that private firefighters may have set illegal backfires as preventive measures against the Glass fire.
item.content:encoded: Allegations have emerged that private firefighters may have set illegal backfires as preventive measures against the Glass fire.

media:content.media:description: CALISTOGA, CA - SEPTEMBER 29: Firefighter uses a drip torch during a firing operation during the Glass Fire slowly creep across a clearing along Silverado Trail (CA-29) on Tuesday, Sept. 29, 2020 in Calistoga, CA. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus could worsen in winter, remain major threat through 2021, Fauci says
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Dr. Anthony Fauci warns the U.S. could be in for a hard winter if coronavirus infections don't come down, during a talk at the Berkeley Forum.
item.content:encoded: Dr. Anthony Fauci warns the U.S. could be in for a hard winter if coronavirus infections don't come down, during a talk at the Berkeley Forum.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 7, 2020, file photo, Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, speaks about the coronavirus in Washington. With New York City at the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak in the U.S. and its native-born among those offering crucial information to the nation in televised briefings, the New York accent has stepped up to the mic. Fauci's science-based way of explaining the crisis at White House briefings has attracted untold numbers of fans, and New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo's news conferences have become must-see TV. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon, File)

item.title: Photos: Closed for months, malls and casinos reopen in Los Angeles County
item.dc:creator: Times Staff
item.description: Malls and casinos in Los Angeles County that have been closed for months because of the COVID-19 pandemic begin to reopen in limited capacities.
item.content:encoded: Malls and casinos in Los Angeles County that have been closed for months because of the COVID-19 pandemic begin to reopen in limited capacities.

media:content.media:description: ARCADIA, CA - OCTOBER 07, 2020 - A woman looks at a positive message in a display at a store inside the Westfield Santa Anita shopping mall in Arcadia on October 7, 2020. This is the first day customers were allowed to return to indoor shopping after Los Angeles County eased restrictions and have reopened the malls and the individual stores. Such stores have been closed for weeks, but reopened Wednesday at 25% capacity. Westfield Santa Anita has placed Covid-related signage with one-way traffic, 6 feet distancing when waiting to get into individual stores, hand sanitizing stations and mask are required before entering the mall. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Tech companies step up to bring free Wi-Fi to L.A. public housing residents
item.dc:creator: Sam Dean
item.description: A new partnership between the mayor's office, Microsoft, and the wireless internet service provider Starry is bringing fast internet to Jordan Downs, Nickerson Gardens and other major public housing complexes in L.A. for the school year
item.content:encoded: A new partnership between the mayor's office, Microsoft, and the wireless internet service provider Starry is bringing fast internet to Jordan Downs, Nickerson Gardens and other major public housing complexes in L.A. for the school year

The group have been friends since high school, which they attended together in the valley. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

This is the first day customers were allowed to return to indoor shopping after Los Angeles County eased restrictions and have reopened the malls and the individual stores. Such stores have been closed for weeks, but reopened Wednesday at 25% capacity. Westfield Santa Anita has placed Covid-related signage with one-way traffic, 6 feet distancing when waiting to get into individual stores, hand sanitizing stations and mask are required before entering the mall. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Nursing home residents want to vote, but amid a pandemic, it is harder than ever
item.dc:creator: Rachel Bluth
item.description: Nursing homes and senior living facilities once hosted voting precincts and made other programs to help residents cast their ballots. But voting is much more difficult this year.
item.content:encoded: Nursing homes and senior living facilities once hosted voting precincts and made other programs to help residents cast their ballots. But voting is much more difficult this year.

media:content.media:description: Hal Alexander, a retired stage manager and director, moved into the Motion Picture and Television Fund's nursing home a few months ago.

item.title: With Prop. 14, California voters will be asked for more borrowing to keep stem cell research going
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: Proposition 14 asks voters to approve $5.5 billion in general obligation bonds for the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine, known as CIRM, for stem cell research.
item.content:encoded: Proposition 14 asks voters to approve $5.5 billion in general obligation bonds for the California Institute for Regenerative Medicine, known as CIRM, for stem cell research.

media:content.media:description: CORONA, CA - OCTOBER 02: Evangelina Vaccaro, 8, was born with no immune system and a disorder commonly known as bubble baby disease. She's been treated and cured with help from money from a previous stem cell bond in California. Alysia Padilla-Vaccaro and her 8-year-old daughter Evangelina Vaccaro are having fun at grandmother's home on Friday, Oct. 2, 2020 in Corona, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column One: L.A. Pride at 50: 'In the beginning it was about visibility. We're here. We're queer. Get used to it.'
item.dc:creator: Maria L. La Ganga
item.description: There were men bedecked in fairy wings. Go-go dancers on a flatbed truck. It was June 28, 1970, and it was the nation's first legally permitted gay pride parade.
item.content:encoded: There were men bedecked in fairy wings. Go-go dancers on a flatbed truck. It was June 28, 1970, and it was the nation's first legally permitted gay pride parade.

item.title: Bound by duty and love, some L.A. Armenians are joining the battle lines in their homeland
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Some Armenian Americans in Southern California have traveled thousands of miles to help in the war effort against Azerbaijan.
item.content:encoded: Some Armenian Americans in Southern California have traveled thousands of miles to help in the war effort against Azerbaijan.

media:content.media:description: Undated handout photo of the Koroghlyan family. David Koroghlyan was visiting family in Armenia when violence broke out on Sept. 27 in a tiny separatist region between neighboring Azerbaijan in the Southern Caucasus. Days later, amid increasingly violent clashes, Koroghlyan put the 10 and 11 year olds back on a plane back home in Los Angeles. He stayed behind to fight.

The event drew about 80 people. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

In an Instagram Live video Thursday, Aug. 20, 2020, hip-hop star Megan Thee Stallion said for the first time that fellow rapper Tory Lanez was the person who pulled the trigger when she was shot in the feet after a party in the Hollywood Hills more than a month earlier. (Photo by Richard Shotwell/Invision/AP, File)

media:content.media:description: In 10 minutes, the Palm Springs Aerial Tramway whisks riders up the steep, rocky slopes of Mt. San Jacinto from 2,643 feet above sea level to 8,516 feet. At top, take in the view, hike or grab a bite.

item.title: Watts' Jordan High cuts association with promoter of eugenics but keeps partial name
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Jordan High in Watts, a school that has graduated generations of Black and Latino students, will drop its association with David Starr Jordan, the founding president of Stanford who figured prominently in the racist practice of eugenics.
item.content:encoded: Jordan High in Watts, a school that has graduated generations of Black and Latino students, will drop its association with David Starr Jordan, the founding president of Stanford who figured prominently in the racist practice of eugenics.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, California-Oct. 7, 2020-Jordan High School graduate Earl Allen, age 75, who graduated in 1962, is president of the alumni association for Jordan High School. Jordan High School in Watts, a school that has graduated generations of Black and Latino students, will drop its association with David Starr Jordan, the founder of Stanford who promoted racial purity. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Protests become a 'lifestyle' for some L.A. activists: 'This has been like church for me'
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Recent protests outside the South L.A. sheriff's station have drawn longtime activists and others who have made attending rallies against police violence part of their weekly routine.
item.content:encoded: Recent protests outside the South L.A. sheriff's station have drawn longtime activists and others who have made attending rallies against police violence part of their weekly routine.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA-SEPT. 10, 2020-Matthew Sanders, age 30, sustained wounds caused by the excessive use of force against protesters by LA County Sheriff deputies. Los Angeles County Sheriff deputies show force as a news conference is held for protesters who claim to have been attacked and injured by L.A. County Sheriff's personnel during recent protests against the shooting death of Dijon Kizzee by deputies on Aug. 31. They plan to discuss the use of "less lethal" weapons, excessive force and unlawful arrests during demonstrations near the Lennox Sheriff's Station. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: Proposition 21 is not about whether there should be government rent control in California. There is and has been for decades. It's about how much â whether it should be substantially strengthened and extended to a lot more housing.

Los Angeles City Councilman Jose Huizar was arrested Tuesday, as he faces charges in the federal investigation into corruption at LA City Hall. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Changes at California's unemployment agency don't do enough to address problems, lawmakers say
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The new online system to expedite applications for jobless benefits was installed after complaints that the EDD's former process was ineffective
item.content:encoded: The new online system to expedite applications for jobless benefits was installed after complaints that the EDD's former process was ineffective

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this July 20, 2010 file photo, people arrive to seek employment opportunities at a JobTrain office in Menlo Park, Calif. On Monday, Aug. 24, 2020, Employment Development Department Director Sharon Hilliard told California lawmakers in Sacramento, California, the state has more than 1 million pending claims for unemployment benefits. Hilliard called the situation "shameful," but said the department is working through the backlog. (AP Photo/Paul Sakuma, File)

This is the first day customers return to indoor shopping after Los Angeles County eases restrictions and have reopened the malls and the individual stores. Such stores have been closed for weeks, but reopened Wednesday at 25% capacity. item.title: On brink of COVID-19 regression, Riverside County revises reopening plan

item.description: An earlier proposal sought to defy state guidelines, but supervisors opted not to push forward with a faster reopening.
item.content:encoded: An earlier proposal sought to defy state guidelines, but supervisors opted not to push forward with a faster reopening.

media:content.media:description: Video frame from a lengthy and at-times tense public meeting, where the Riverside County Board of Supervisors voted Tuesday in favor of a continued COVID-19 reopening plan. Riverside County supervisor Jeff Hewitt was the lone vote against the plan - but only because he wanted even looser guidelines than those put forth by the state.

item.title: Can California ban fracking? Newsom's bold plan to fight climate change faces skepticism
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna, Phil Willon
item.description: California lawmakers say Gov. Gavin Newsom must do more than endorse a fracking ban for the Legislature to take action.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers say Gov. Gavin Newsom must do more than endorse a fracking ban for the Legislature to take action.

media:content.media:description: On the hood of an electric car, California Gov. Gavin Newsom signs an executive order requiring all new passenger vehicles sold in the state to be zero-emission by 2035 after a press conference on Wednesday, Sept. 23, 2020, at Cal Expo in Sacramento. It's a move the governor says would achieve a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. California would be the first state with such a rule, though Germany and France are among 15 other countries that have a similar requirement. (Daniel Kim/The Sacramento Bee via AP, Pool)

item.title: Two girls and their father dead in apparent murder-suicide in Placentia, police say
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: Two young girls and their father were found dead in an apparent murder-suicide in Placentia. The father is suspected of stabbing his daughters to death and then stabbing himself.
item.content:encoded: Two young girls and their father were found dead in an apparent murder-suicide in Placentia. The father is suspected of stabbing his daughters to death and then stabbing himself.

media:content.media:description: PLACENTIA CALIFORNIA OCTOBER 7, 2020 - An investigation is underway after a man was found dead in a Placentia neighborhood and is suspected of taking his own life after fatally stabbing his two children in a nearby home early Wednesday morning, October 7, 2020. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Family of homeless Black man fatally shot in San Clemente files claim against O.C. Sheriff's Department
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: The family of Kurt Reinhold, a homeless Black man who was fatally shot by deputies in San Clemente, files a claim against the Orange County Sheriff's Department, seeking "justice and transparency."
item.content:encoded: The family of Kurt Reinhold, a homeless Black man who was fatally shot by deputies in San Clemente, files a claim against the Orange County Sheriff's Department, seeking "justice and transparency."

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA, CA - OCTOBER 06: Latoya Reinhold, widow of Kurt Reinhold, reads a prepared statement at a press conference where family attorneys discussed details of the claim against the Orange County Sheriff's Department and its deputies for the wrongful death of Kurt Reinhold in San Clemente on September 23, 2020. Reinhold is joined by other members of Kurt Reinhold's family. Photo taken in Central Justice Center on Tuesday, Oct. 6, 2020 in Santa Ana, CA. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newsom's pick for California high court talks about coming out: 'My journey was different'
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Martin Jenkins, 66, who will become the first openly gay California Supreme Court justice, said he began coming out in the past five years.
item.content:encoded: Martin Jenkins, 66, who will become the first openly gay California Supreme Court justice, said he began coming out in the past five years.

media:content.media:description: Martin Jenkins was appointed to a seat on the California Supreme Court.
media:content.media:credit: Martin Jenkins was appointed to a seat on the California Supreme Court.

item.title: This was supposed to be the year for California's homeless. Instead it's a slow 'train wreck'
item.dc:creator: Anna Maria Barry-Jester, Angela Hart
item.description: Interviews statewide reveal a new magnitude of hardship and indignity for tens of thousands of people living on the streets, as COVID-19 upended promises made early in 2019.
item.content:encoded: Interviews statewide reveal a new magnitude of hardship and indignity for tens of thousands of people living on the streets, as COVID-19 upended promises made early in 2019.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 08, 2020 - - Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) outreach worker Monica Palma, center, visits with Kim M. and her dog Dee-O-G who live homeless under the Santa Monica freeway along Venice Blvd. in Los Angeles on July 8, 2020. Victor Hinderliter, background, right, associate director with Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA), and LAHSA outreach worker Brandon Rincon, third from right, visit with Jesse James Taylor, 50, at his encampment. The city and county of Los Angeles plan to move people from the freeways. U.S. District Judge David O. Carter passed a landmark court order banning homeless encampments from under and along Los Angeles freeways. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Serious COVID-19 outbreaks hit California colleges despite intense preparation
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Newly reopened colleges weren't prepared for the influx of college students residing off-campus that have contributed to COVID-19 outbreaks.
item.content:encoded: Newly reopened colleges weren't prepared for the influx of college students residing off-campus that have contributed to COVID-19 outbreaks.

media:content.media:description: Over 300 unmasked people - mostly in large groups - were seen partying in Isla Vista, near the campus of UC Santa Barbara, on the evenings of Friday, Aug. 28 and Saturday, Aug. 29. Community members and university officials have been concerned about the spread of COVID-19 in Isla Vista,

item.title: California voters to decide whether to end cash bail system with Proposition 25
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The referendum vote comes more than two years after a bitter legislative fight that pitted the multibillion-dollar bail industry, criminal defense attorneys and some civil liberties advocates against Democratic leaders.
item.content:encoded: The referendum vote comes more than two years after a bitter legislative fight that pitted the multibillion-dollar bail industry, criminal defense attorneys and some civil liberties advocates against Democratic leaders.

media:content.media:description: A person walks past Bad Boys Bail Bonds in Los Angeles.

item.title: Hundreds protest outside L.A. Times over coverage of Armenia-Azerbaijan conflict
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The protesters shut down Imperial Highway and Douglas Street about 6 p.m. Tuesday, with some chanting, "Shame on the L.A. Times."
item.content:encoded: The protesters shut down Imperial Highway and Douglas Street about 6 p.m. Tuesday, with some chanting, "Shame on the L.A. Times."

media:content.media:description: EL SEGUNDO, CA - OCTOBER 06: Suzanna Gevorgyan holds a flag from Artsakh, the disputed region inside Azerbaijan with an Armenian majority population and Haykaz Martirosyan waves an Armenian flag, while More than 1,000 people supporting Armenia with flags, signs and song, gathered in protest of the Los Angeles Times using a quote from the Consul General of Azerbaijan, in a story about the current conflict in the contested Nagorno-Karabakh region between Armenia and Azerbaijan, outside the Los Angeles Times headquarters, in El Segundo, CA,Tuesday, Oct. 6, 2020. Fighting broke out in the region, which Armenians call by its historic name, Artsakh, at the end of September with each side accusing the other of escalation and targeting civilian areas. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Haliburton International Foods CEO charged with child prostitution

item.description: The Orange County D.A. announced that Ian Charles Schenkel faces years in prison.
item.content:encoded: The Orange County D.A. announced that Ian Charles Schenkel faces years in prison.

item.title: L.A. district attorney to review allegation that Villanueva made false report
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian
item.description: The D.A. is reviewing allegations that Sheriff Alex Villanueva falsely reported a crime when he accused the county's chief executive of violating conflict of interest laws.
item.content:encoded: The D.A. is reviewing allegations that Sheriff Alex Villanueva falsely reported a crime when he accused the county's chief executive of violating conflict of interest laws.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- WEDNESDAY, APRIL 24, 2019: L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva waits to speak during a media open house at the Hall of Justice in Los Angeles, Calif., on April 24, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: What caused California's rolling blackouts? Climate change and poor planning
item.dc:creator: Sammy Roth
item.description: The state recently experienced four of its five hottest August days in the last 35 years â and its power grid wasn't prepared.
item.content:encoded: The state recently experienced four of its five hottest August days in the last 35 years â and its power grid wasn't prepared.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Saturday, Aug. 15, 2020, file photo, electrical grid transmission towers are seen in Pasadena, Calif. As if the pandemic and recession weren't bad enough, millions of Californians have been facing the recurring threats of abrupt blackouts during a heat wave in the nation's most populous state. (AP Photo/John Antczak, File)

item.title: Glass fire firefighter hospitalized after possible carbon monoxide poisoning

item.title: Flaws in LAPD's process for accepting outside donations cited; fixes promised

item.content:encoded: Los Angeles police officials promised improvements to the LAPD's process for accepting donations after two audits identified issues with documenting and tracking such gifts.

item.title: In a first, 2 counties move backward on state's reopening plan; Ventura moves forward
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A handful of counties advanced on the state's COVID-19 reopening measuring stick, including Ventura County, the fourth county in Southern California to expand its reopening.
item.content:encoded: A handful of counties advanced on the state's COVID-19 reopening measuring stick, including Ventura County, the fourth county in Southern California to expand its reopening.

item.title: Transgender woman 'brutally stabbed' in targeted attack at MacArthur Park, police say
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector, Faith E. Pinho
item.description: Attack on transgender woman prompts dozens of people to gather at MacArthur Park to call for an end to violence and declare the area a "safe space."
item.content:encoded: Attack on transgender woman prompts dozens of people to gather at MacArthur Park to call for an end to violence and declare the area a "safe space."

media:content.media:description: Daniela Hernandez, who was attacked Sunday in MacArthur Park, volunteered regularly at the TransLatina Coalition, serving food to people in her community.

item.content:encoded: The demonstration may have been linked to the weekend shooting of an unarmed Black man in Texas whose name was written by protesters at the scene.

item.title: Op-Ed: Prevent future L.A. City Council scandals by fixing our planning system
item.dc:creator: Rick Cole, Gail Goldberg, Bud Ovrom
item.description: The recent L.A. City Council scandals show, again, the need for reform to prevent developers from undue political influence. Here's how a commission could help do that.
item.content:encoded: The recent L.A. City Council scandals show, again, the need for reform to prevent developers from undue political influence. Here's how a commission could help do that.
